snp1.4:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Magadhans in the Southern Hills near the brahmin village of Ekanāḷa.
snp1.4:1.3: Now at that time the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Farmer had harnessed around five hundred plows, it being the season for sowing.
snp1.4:1.4: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to where Bhāradvāja the Farmer was working.
snp1.4:1.5: Now at that time Bhāradvāja the Farmer was distributing food.
snp1.4:1.6: Then the Buddha went to where the distribution was taking place and stood to one side.
snp1.4:2.1: Bhāradvāja the Farmer saw him standing for alms
snp1.4:2.3: “I plough and sow, ascetic, and then I eat.
snp1.4:2.5: You too should plough and sow, then you may eat.”
snp1.4:3.1: “I too plough and sow, brahmin, and then I eat.”
snp1.4:3.3: “I don’t see Master Gotama with a yoke or plow or plowshare or goad or oxen, yet he says:
snp1.4:3.5: “I too plough and sow, brahmin, and then I eat.”
snp1.4:4.1: Then Bhāradvāja the Farmer addressed the Buddha in verse:
snp1.4:5.2: but I don’t see your plough.
snp1.4:5.3: If you’re a farmer, declare to me:
snp1.4:5.4: so that we can know a brahmin.”
snp1.4:6.1: “Faith is my seed, austerity my rain,
snp1.4:6.2: and wisdom is my yoke and plough.
snp1.4:6.3: Conscience is my pole, mind my strap,
snp1.4:7.2: I restrict my intake of food.
snp1.4:7.3: I use truth as my scythe,
snp1.4:8.1: Energy is my beast of burden,
snp1.4:8.2: transporting me to a place of sanctuary.
snp1.4:9.1: That’s how to do the farming
snp1.4:9.2: that has the Deathless as its fruit.
snp1.4:10.1: Then Bhāradvāja the Farmer filled a large bronze dish with milk-rice and presented it to the Buddha:
snp1.4:10.4: For Master Gotama does the farming that has the Deathless as its fruit.”
snp1.4:11.1: “Food enchanted by a spell isn’t fit for me to eat.
snp1.4:11.2: That’s not the way of those who see, brahmin.
snp1.4:11.3: The Buddhas reject things enchanted with spells.
snp1.4:11.4: Since nature is real, brahmin, that’s how they live.
